But how many are you actually

I want to talk about today

interaction as a key element of human-computer interaction.

How do we focus on that as a
phenomenon in its own right? And how can we do it

How can we be inspired by theory

Susanne Bodker from the
University of Oslo, and me. And we want to think

mean to do generative theory. If you're doing
research-- and you should all pay
attention to this.

If you look at the
natural sciences, you have two different
things that happen.

You have formation of theory and
you have empirical observation.

Formation of theory
is often done where you talk about a theory,
you test it with an experiment,

and then you go back and
you revise your theory. And there are a variety of
sciences, natural sciences,

that work that way. So if you're in
physics, for example, or if you're in biology,
you might have the DNA,

the double helix, or something. And you say, OK,
we have this idea of how the DNA is
structured, and we're going

to go and do studies of that. And then we're going to go
back and revise it based on our empirical understanding. But there are also other
equally legitimate sciences,

natural sciences now, that start
with empirical observation, develop theory, and then go
back and test with observation.

So, in those cases, you have
things like astrophysics, you have geology, you
have anthropology.

Those are cases where you
have to look at the real world and you want to get the
richness of the real world.

So what's really
interesting in HCI is that we have both of these. And research in HCI
deals with both,

but there's something
missing, all right. And what's missing is
the fact that we're

dealing with artifacts. And we're dealing with artifacts
that we create ourselves. They're human-created
artifacts like this.

And there are
physical properties to this that I can study,
but the whole notion

of interaction with
technology and these artifacts that we create is, has to
be dealt with in a slightly

different way. This is what Herb Simon
talks about in the sciences of the artificial. We are doing science but with
respect to created artifacts.

They're not things that
exist independently of us. They're things that
we're involved with. So now what that means is that
we have, in HCI, this theory,

empirical observation. We look at users. We create theories about
what should be going-- good ways of designing things.

And then we actually
build technology. And my argument to you, if
you're doing research in HCI,

is that you should be
doing a complete path. You should be going from
theory, through artifact,

to observation, and
back up to theory, or you should start
with observation, go through design, and up.

If you're just going across
the middle, you're in industry. That's fine.

That's good. You're just not doing research. And there are people who do
things-- like a lot of AI

is going from theory to
artifact, theory to artifact. That's one kind of thing.

There's other people who go
from observation to design, that's a different thing.

But to do research
in HCI, I will argue-- there are people
who disagree with me, but I will argue that you
should do the complete path.

Now another way
of looking at this is that we have a set
of design methods. And again, that's what this book
is about, and the other kinds

of things that we do. How do we interview people? How do we do a
generative walkthrough? How do we think about gathering
information from users,

and having that influence our
designs, and then figuring out whether those designs work? There's a lot of that
in HCI and there's

a lot of that in UX design. Some of it more
rigorous than others, but basically,
there's a lot of that.

What's often
missing is this bit. How do we think about
theory, and how does that

inform our design? How do we do what we
call generative theory? Now if you look at theory,
depends on which discipline

you're coming from. I'm a kind of weird case
because I started out as an experimental psychologist,
then I spent a bunch of time

with anthropologists
and sociologists. I spent a bunch of time
in computer science.

I spent a little
time in management. Worked in industry,
worked in academia.

I've just gone back
and forth and worked with lots of different people. And what I learned in that
is that the shape of theory

matters and it's different. So we have descriptive
theories, and that's what you do when
you're trying to-- you

see a phenomenon out there
and you want to describe it and you just want to
see if it matches.

Then there's predictive
theory, which is, I can understand
what's happening here and I can predict
what will happen next.

And there tends to be a
more quantitative element to that but not always. And then there's the
notion of control.

So if you come from
behaviorism, for example, you're controlling human
behavior or animal behavior. If you're going
to train your dog,

you want to control
that behavior. That's a different
path of theory. What we're talking
about is something

that's a little bit
orthogonal, which is what we call generative theory. The idea is that
we have theories

that we can take
from different places and use them to
inform our design.

So the idea of a generative
theory of interaction, which is what's
in this paper, is

that we take empirical theories
that exist outside of HCI. They can come from psychology,
sociology, evolutionary biology,

you name it. But the problem we
generally have is those are broad theories,
and the researchers

who create those theories
do not create them with the idea of helping
us design artifacts.

They just don't. It's not their goal. They want to
understand the world. They're natural
scientists, in that sense,

or social scientists,
but their goal is to understand the phenomenon. So what we need to do is
we take the next step.

We start creating and
developing concepts that allow us to
articulate what's

relevant from
those theories that are well-established
but relevant to HCI.

And then we create a set
of generative principles. These are actionable principles.

These are things that we can
look at specifically and say, if I follow that
principle, I can

take advantage of the
knowledge that they've developed in these other fields
and apply it to my design.

All right, so how do we do that? Well, we argue that you can
start with existing artifacts

and apply an analytical lens,
which is to basically take these analytical
principles, look

at that particular
piece of technology, and figure out whether
it's even there.

The next thing that you can do-- so that's that, and it's
kind of like, is it there? The arrows go slowly.

And then we can have a critical
lens, which we can apply both to things that exist
and also to new things.

And here, the idea is would
this system be better off if we use this principle?

Can we put a value
judgment on it? And here, basically,
that can help

us think about improving
an existing system or creating a new one.

And finally, we have
a generative lens, which is how can we use these
principles to actually create

something that's new? And we find that this is
an extremely powerful way of creating new
technology and new ideas.

So in the paper, we
have three examples. There's instrumental
interaction, which is something that we use a lot.

This is based on human tool
use and technical reasoning. And what I'm going to talk

here are coming out of evolutionary biology.

The way species and animals
co-adapt, not co-evolution. Co-adaptation

It has been elaborated since. And the notion of the
adjacent possible, which is, in a
nutshell, if you imagine

you have a single-cell
organism, there's only so much you
can do around that.

You're not going to go

But if you have two of these and

multicellular organism,

or maybe I have
a nucleus inside. And once I have the
idea of multiple ones,

build on the set of things

today. So let's think about
what's happening when we're talking to computers.

Three basic oversimplified
ways of thinking about our relationship
with the computer. I can think about me
interacting with this as a tool.

And that's basically where
we've been, historically, in human-computer interaction. We think about creating
interactive tools

that we can apply and use
to solve different problems for ourselves. And a lot of what we do

in this field. Another one is the idea that we
tell the system to do something

And a lot of this sort of
notion that the human doesn't have to do it, we're going to

So when we're dealing

We can think about how to place

It can be something

You can also augment

is being done today,

which I object to. Not because I don't
think that there's some incredible
potential for AI,

systems that we see are changing the way

And I have to actively shift and

So when we're thinking about
dealing with AI systems, we have to think about
how is that embedded

And it matters what

So we should be paying attention
not just to the algorithm, but the way it's embedded
in real technology

that we human beings use. Now part of the
reason for this is the way that machine
learning algorithms

be true. You read your data. You calculate it. You find some patterns. And then you produce the
results, and it's very linear.

I send you something. Calculate, calculate,

when you do that, when

you think of it that way,
it's very tempting as an AI researcher to define the user's
role as either a source of data

to help your algorithm--

So you want better data for

cryptology or cybersecurity,

they're the ones who are talking
about, the main source of error is the person in the

Users as a source of
error, really annoying. Messes up my algorithm. And you can also think of it as
just basically another component

of the machine. If you're doing neural

neural network. And the human brain
is just like that,

and it's all one big sheet. But none of those are

doing an HCI perspective.

You really want to think about
what is the impact on the user. So there's a number of things.

detail on all of this, but basically, there
are a lot of issues

a really nice rapid

Except that it can be wrong. And Boeing did it so it didn't

And you had 14 seconds--

So this was AI being introduced

Boeing and those planes

So we have to be
careful in any kind of safety-critical system about
how we're going to do this. Now another thing
that I want you

to think about as HCI people
who are going to sometimes be doing AI yourself and
sometimes working with people

who do AI is keep in mind
that a different algorithm with the same interaction can
produce the same result. So

what matters overall
is the interaction. And we have a project
on sustainable AI.

And the idea is can we use
less intensive algorithms to get the same result from
the user's point of view?

And similarly and
very importantly, the same algorithm with a
slightly different interaction

can produce radically
different results on the user. Classic example-- not a classic
example, a good example,

think of ship captains
going into the harbor and they've got to plot
a route into the harbor.

And they've got this nice
AI system and it comes in and it tells them a route. And it took them about
two weeks before they just

said, no, no, no, no,
because, what it's doing is de-skilling them. And they don't know why
it produced that thing.

Same algorithm, same system,
different interaction, slight difference.

Now the pilot-- the
captain, excuse me, the captain plots the course
first, and the system comes back

and it, says OK, that's good,
but you could have done this and you could have done that. And then they're evaluating
their own work with respect

to other possibilities, and
they are thinking about it. Now we're upskilling. Now we're making them better.

Same algorithm,
different interaction. Interaction matters. OK, so keep in mind that a
better, intelligent algorithm

is neither necessary
nor sufficient to create a better intelligent system.

So we have a large
group of people who are working on
better algorithms. More power to them
let them do that.

We will use the
results of their work. But it's critical that we
think about how we interact

with those
algorithms, otherwise, we create all kinds of problems. OK, so there is this notion
of human in the loop.

Here, the idea is-- the perspective from AI is
we're going to measure success--

if you go to a
NeurIPS Conference, you're going to be measured
on how good is your algorithm. Did it perform better?

And what I suggest we should
have is something closer to computer-in-the-loop, where
we think about the measure

of success is, is the
human being better off? And that's a critical shift. It's not necessarily
fundamentally different

in terms of that loop. It's still a loop, human,
computer, human, computer, but it's a different way
of thinking about it.

The other thing is that we
want to think about interaction over time and the fact
that people change

their behavior over time. And This is starting
to get to this idea of human-computer partnerships.

So there's an interactive
loop, and we're responding-- the computer
is responding to the user's

actions, but the user
is also responding to what the computer does. All right, now I want to
say one last thing, which

is from a research perspective. We are always facing
a challenge, which is when we're trying to design
a new system, we want to have--

give the user the maximal
power of expression, number of different ways of
doing things, and giving them

a powerful way of doing that. Programming languages

Now what you get, in contrast,

buttons and those

are easy to push, but very
low power of expression. So we have this compromise
between power of expression

and simplicity of interaction. And I would argue that that
trade-off is always there.

However, as researchers,
we have a challenge, which is can we move that curve?

We can't get rid
of the trade-off, but we can move the curve. So we can do things where
we keep simple things simple

and we allow complex
things to be possible. And for a system that's
this level of complexity,

in terms of power
of expression, can I make it simpler
or can I add power to something that's that
level of simplicity?

And we have a number
of different examples of that in our-- you
can look on our website if you want to
see some examples.

So how do we create
interactive systems where we have AI integrated?

So we want to combine this
idea of the computer as a tool. It's an interactive tool that
we can manipulate and do things

with. And we want to
think about how we can use those tools to augment
our human capabilities.

And we can also take advantage
of the computer as a servant, and being able to take
over certain tasks

that we want to do. But the challenge I maintain
is to keep the user in control.

So we want it not treat
people as a source of data for the algorithm,
but basically,

consider algorithms as a source
of information to the user. And I don't mean explainability
in the traditional AI

sense, which is like, "Let me
explain this algorithm to you," because most users don't care. It has to be understandable,
a source of information

relative to what
the user wants to do in the context of
their particular work.

All right, so how
do we empower users? How do we help them gain skills? How do we help them
control the interaction?

Well, I argue that we create
these things that we call human-computer partnerships. And the idea is
to take advantage

of the best features of
both because human beings and computers are
very different. They have some shared
skills but a lot

of very different capabilities. So let me think about what
do I mean as a metaphor

here for what is a partnership. So if you think about
taking a taxi or an Uber

or a Lyft or whatever, you say,
"I want to go to that place." And say it's been Saturday
night and I'm out drinking,

and I really shouldn't drive,
I want to delegate the driving to somebody else. And so a taxi lets me do that.

I can give that control
over to somebody else. And I just give them
the address and hope

that they'll get me there. By contrast, you have
something where you really

enjoy the type of
transportation you're doing, say, driving a motorcycle. You've had to learn how
to ride that motorcycle.

You had to get
certified, and so on. But you really like going
out on a Saturday afternoon and going through to
Marin County or wherever

and you're riding around
and you're having fun. That's great. You maintain control.

But is there something
that lets us do both? And I would argue that the
metaphor here is one of a horse.

So a horse is intelligent but
not the way you're intelligent. But they can get you places
and they can take you home

if you're drunk
because they know where home is if you're close enough. But you can also go jumping and
riding and do things with that.

And the idea is
that you can learn-- both of you learn to each
other, you adapt to each other.

You learn to get better
riding the horse. The horse learns to
interact with you and learns things from you.

And the idea is can
we create partnerships that have some of
these characteristics, where there's some intelligence
that's different from our own--

and our own intelligence
and we can learn over time how to control that interaction? OK, so now human-computer
partnerships

is the marketing
term for what we call reciprocal co-adaptation. And co-adaptation, as
I mentioned before,

comes from evolutionary biology,
but it's been applied to how we co-adapt with technology, not
with species and individuals

co-adapting in a-- well, in evolutionary
biology terms. So the idea is that there's
four different relationships

you can have. I, as a user, can
adapt to the technology that's there, which means
I adapt my behavior.

I learn how the system works. And if you're in UX,
design you're always thinking about, oh, create
the user experience.

And it's this very
simplistic kind of, OK, that's one thing we'll do. We will let people
learn the right thing.

Actually, I realized that
I should have had all four. So I'm going to have to
say the four and then--

the other thing that you can do
is you can adapt the technology. You can appropriate it.

You can change it. You can make it different. And so if I have, for
example, this water bottle--

this is great. Oh, I'm glad I have
a water bottle. I can use this to drink
from, but I could also

use it to prop up this book. I can adapt its properties. This is the notion of
affordances, which I'm

sure you've all heard about. But the idea is that there are
properties in the physical world that we can take advantage of.

And we always use
those properties and manipulate
them to make things happen the way we want to.

So we are adapting
the world around us. And it's a phenomenon that
happens in evolutionary terms

and on local terms. And the thing is we can
take advantage of that. Now that's co-adaptation
from the human perspective.

Interestingly, you
have the reverse, which is the system can
learn from us as users.

It can collect data
about us and it can figure out things about us. And it can modify its behavior
according to what we do.

The other thing it can do is
it can manipulate our behavior. It can adapt us.

It can appropriate how we're
working and make us do things. Now that could be good.

We learn stuff. It can make us
learn things or it can persuade us to buy things
that we probably shouldn't buy.

So there's a whole
set of principles from experimental psychology,
and particularly, behaviorism,

about how to control
human behavior. So there are four
different things going on in reciprocal co-adaptation.
